details.title: Fuzzy Rule-Based Bayesian Reasoning Approach for Prioritization of Failures in FMEA
details.standardTitle: Fuzzy Rule-Based Bayesian Reasoning Approach for Prioritization of Failures in FMEA

p: Zaili Yang received his B.Sc. in Foreign Trade Transportation from Dalian Maritime University, China in 2001; M.Sc. in International Transport from Cardiff University in 2003; and Ph.D. in Marine Technology from Liverpool John Moores University, UK in 2006. He is a Lecturer at the School of Engineering of Liverpool John Moores University.
Dr. Yang's major research interests include maritime safety and security analysis, safety based decision making, and uncertainty treatment in risk assessment.

authors.affiliation: Sch. of Eng., Liverpool John Moores Univ., Liverpool
authors.name: Zaili Yang

p: Steve Bonsall received his B.Sc. in Marine Science from Liverpool Polytechnic, UK in 1977, and Ph.D. in Maritime Technology from Liverpool John Moores University, UK in 2001. He is currently the Head of Maritime, Transport, and Management in the School of Engineering of Liverpool John Moores University, UK.
Dr. Bonsall's major research interests include container terminal operations, and container supply chains.

Jin Wang received his B.Sc. in Marine Automation from Dalian Maritime University, China in 1983; and M.Sc. in Marine Engineering, and Ph.D. in Maritime Safety Engineering from the University of Newcastle upon Tyne, UK in 1989, and 1994, respectively. He is Professor of Marine Technology at the School of Engineering of Liverpool John Moores University, UK.
Prof. Wang's major research interests include safety and reliability based design and operations of large marine and offshore systems.

details.abstract: This paper presents a novel, efficient fuzzy rule-based Bayesian reasoning (FuRBaR) approach for prioritizing failures in failure mode and effects analysis (FMEA). The technique is specifically intended to deal with some of the drawbacks concerning the use of conventional fuzzy logic (i.e. rule-based) methods in FMEA. In the proposed approach, subjective belief degrees are assigned to the consequent part of the rules to model the incompleteness encountered in establishing the knowledge base. A Bayesian reasoning mechanism is then used to aggregate all relevant rules for assessing and prioritizing potential failure modes. A series of case studies of collision risk between a floating, production, storage, and off loading (FPSO) system and a shuttle tanker caused by technical failure during tandem off loading operation is used to illustrate the application of the proposed model. The reliability of the new approach is tested by using a benchmarking technique (with a well-established fuzzy rule-based evidential reasoning method), and a sensitivity analysis of failure priority values.

links.abstract: The analysis of system reliability often requires the use of subjective-judgments, uncertain data, and approximate system models. By allowing imprecision and approximate analysis fuzzy logic provides an effective tool for characterizing system reliability in these circumstances; it does not force precision where it is not possible. Here we apply the main concepts of fuzzy logic, fuzzy arithmetic and linguistic variables to the analysis of system structures, fault trees, event trees, the reliabil...

links.abstract: Analysts are sometimes asked to make frequency estimates for specific accidents in which the accident frequency is determined primarily by safety controls. Under these conditions, frequency estimates use considerable expert belief in determining how the controls affect the accident frequency. To evaluate and document beliefs about control effectiveness, they have modified a traditional Bayesian approach by using approximate reasoning (AR) to develop prior distributions. context.text: To overcome such intrinsic drawbacks, many new methods based on uncertainty treatment theories such as fuzzy logic [4], [27], Dempster-Shafer theory [19], grey theory [7], [21], Monte Carlo simulation [2], Bayesian nets [17], Markov models [9], and artificial neural networks [15] have been proposed in the literature to enhance the performance of \$FMEA\$.

To overcome the weakness of the loss of useful information in fuzzy risk inference, a fuzzy rule-based evidential reasoning \$(FRBER)\$ approach [19] has been introduced to synthesize IF-THEN rules with belief structures in a comprehensive manner for appropriate risk/failure analysis.
Dealing with complex calculations for producing “precise” risk results without losing too much information in the process of fuzzy inference [19].

While the conventional rule base is constructed to represent fuzziness, it has been criticized [19] due to the fact that the consequence may sometimes not be able to reflect slight changes of linguistic variables occurring in the antecedence.
A collection of belief rules consists of a \$FRB\$ with complete belief structure defined as follows [19].
The recent literature survey indicates that the linguistic variables used to describe \$L,\,C\$, and \$P\$ of a particular failure may be defined as follows [19], [23].
In this study, a benchmarking technique is used to compare the \$FuRBaR\$ method with a well-established \$FRBER\$ inference approach [19], [28] through analyzing their correlation.

Pillay & Wang [21] have developed a fuzzy logic approach to overcome the conversion debate by directly evaluating the linguistic assessment of \$FMEA\$ attributes, and applied the grey theory to obtain a risk priority number by assigning relative weighting coefficients.

context.text:
The utility values can be defined on the basis of the combination of specific fuzzy rules [26] and preference numbers through satisfying the following conditions.

1)IF very low \$(L1)\$, and negligible \$(C1)\$, and highly unlikely \$(P1)\$, THEN \$\{(1,good\ (S1)),(0,average\ (S2)),\,\,(0,fair\ (S3)),\break(0, poor\ (S4))\}\$.
2)IF reasonably low \$(L3)\$, and marginal \$(C2)\$, and reasonably unlikely \$(P3)\$, THEN \$\{(0,good\ (S1)),(1,average\ (S2)),\,\,(0,fair\ (S3)),\break(0,poor\ (S4))\}\$.
3)IF reasonably high \$(L5)\$, and critical \$(C4)\$, and reasonably likely \$(P5)\$, THEN \$\{(0,good\ (S1)),(0,average\ (S2)),\,\,(1,fair\ (S3)),\break(0,poor\ (S4))\}\$.
4)IF very high \$(L7)\$, and catastrophic \$(C5)\$, and highly likely \$(P7)\$, THEN \$\{(0,good\ (S1)),(0,average\ (S2)),\,\,(0,fair\ (S3)),\break(1,poor\ (S4))\}\$.
5)The preference degree \$PN\$ of each linguistic term \$Li,\,Cj\$, or \$Pk\ (i=1,\ldots,7,j=1,\ldots,5,k=1,\ldots,7)\$ is described using a preference number in the scale [1, 10], where 1 indicates “slightly preferred”, and 10 means the “greatly preferred” in terms of safety contributions.

context.text: Although showing much attractiveness, such a method still reveals some applicable problems, especially when criticality analysis is concerned [6], [22], [27].

To overcome such intrinsic drawbacks, many new methods based on uncertainty treatment theories such as fuzzy logic [4], [27], Dempster-Shafer theory [19], grey theory [7], [21], Monte Carlo simulation [2], Bayesian nets [17], Markov models [9], and artificial neural networks [15] have been proposed in the literature to enhance the performance of \$FMEA\$.
Shortcomings of the traditional Risk Priority Number \$(RPN)\$ approach have been extensively analysed [6], [27].
Xu et al., [27] have proposed an improved fuzzy rule-based \$FMEA\$ model, which addressed the question of the vague estimations of the three attributes composing the original \$RPN\$ method.

links.abstract: In this paper, a generic rule-base inference methodology using the evidential reasoning (RIMER) approach is proposed. Existing knowledge-base structures are first examined, and knowledge representation schemes under uncertainty are then briefly analyzed. Based on this analysis, a new knowledge representation scheme in a rule base is proposed using a belief structure. In this scheme, a rule base is designed with belief degrees embedded in all possible consequents of a rule. Such a rule base is ca...
